extendedIngredients.name: capers

extendedIngredients.name: dry white wine
extendedIngredients.original: 1/4 cup dry white wine, preferably Sicilian

extendedIngredients.name: oil cured black olives
extendedIngredients.original: 1/4 cup pitted oil-cured black olives coarsely chopped
extendedIngredients.originalName: pitted oil-cured black olives coarsely chopped

extendedIngredients.name: sun-dried tomatoes
extendedIngredients.original: 1/3 cup sun-dried tomatoes packed in oil

extendedIngredients.name: yellow onion

extendedIngredients.originalName: yellow onion, halved and thinly sliced

title: Sicilian-style Swordfish
summary: Sicilian-style Swordfish might be just the main course you are searching for. One serving contains 375 calories, 36g of protein, and 20g of fat. This caveman, gluten free, dairy free, and primal recipe serves 4 and costs $5.2 per serving. Head to the store and pick up sun-dried tomatoes, garlic cloves, pepper, and a few other things to make it today. 33 people were impressed by this recipe. From preparation to the plate, this recipe takes roughly 45 minutes. All things considered, we decided this recipe deserves a spoonacular score of 89%. This score is spectacular. Try Swordfish, Sicilian Style, Swordfish, Sicilian Style, and Swordfish Sicilian-Style for similar recipes.

winePairing.pairingText: Pinot Grigio, Gruener Veltliner, and Pinot Noir are my top picks for Fish. Fish is as diverse as wine, so it's hard to pick wines that go with every fish. A crisp white wine, such as a pinot grigio or Gr√ºner Veltliner, will suit any delicately flavored white fish. Meaty, strongly flavored fish such as salmon and tuna can even handle a light red wine, such as a pinot noir. The Loveblock Pinot Gris with a 4.6 out of 5 star rating seems like a good match. It costs about 24 dollars per bottle.

productMatches.title: Loveblock Pinot Gris
productMatches.description: Loveblock Pinot Gris is a pale golden with hints of green. The 2013 vintage is a dry style with floral aromas and a hint of ripe pineapple. The palate reveals poached pear and blood orange, and finishes with a touch of citrus, good texture and rich mouth feel.

instructions: In a large skillet (one wide enough to hold swordfish in a single layer), heat oil over medium-high heat.                                   Add onion and garlic; cook, stirring frequently, until onion is lightly browned, 3 to 4 minutes. Remove from heat.                                   Add sun-dried tomatoes, olives, capers, wine and generous pinch red pepper flakes; stir together. Transfer to bowl.                                  Lightly season swordfish with salt and pepper; in a single layer, place fish in skillet.                                   Return skillet to medium-high heat, cover and cook for 3 minutes per side.                                   When swordfish is cooked through and browned, cover with sauce and warm.                                  Sprinkle roughly torn basil and serve.  This dish can also be served room temperature.

steps.step: In a large skillet (one wide enough to hold swordfish in a single layer), heat oil over medium-high heat.
Add onion and garlic; cook, stirring frequently, until onion is lightly browned, 3 to 4 minutes.
Add sun-dried tomatoes, olives, capers, wine and generous pinch red pepper flakes; stir together.
Lightly season swordfish with salt and pepper; in a single layer, place fish in skillet.
Return skillet to medium-high heat, cover and cook for 3 minutes per side.
When swordfish is cooked through and browned, cover with sauce and warm.
Sprinkle roughly torn basil and serve.  This dish can also be served room temperature.
